thread.title: SAN BERNARDINO: Gettin' your kicks at the Rendezvous Back to Route 66
thread.title_full: SAN BERNARDINO: Gettin' your kicks at the Rendezvous Back to Route 66 - Press Enterprise

author: LAURIE WILLIAMS
title: SAN BERNARDINO: Gettin' your kicks at the Rendezvous Back to Route 66
text:
BY LAURIE WILLIAMS / CONTRIBUTING WRITER
Published: Oct. 10, 2015 Updated: 10:15 p.m. Gary DeVince's red 1965 Mustang has always been a San Bernardino car – its first owner bought it at Garner Ford on D Street.
"It's right where it belongs," DeVince said, referring to his car's prime spot on Arrowhead Avenue, backed into a diagonal space with its hood open for inspection by passersby.
DeVince and his wife, Jennifer, were among hundreds of people who brought their lovingly restored and maintained vintage vehicles to downtown San Bernardino on Saturday for the third annual Rendezvous Back to Route 66, a salute to cruiser culture, and especially of the muscle cars of the 1960s and 1970s.
Shiny classic cars lined the streets downtown, or showed their stuff along the event's L-shaped cruise route.
At various points along the route, entrants stopped to let the crowd hear their powerful engines roar.
DeVince said he sometimes does that – his Mustang's 347 Stroker motor has a lot more oomph than the one it came with off the assembly line.
"We're not doing it today," Jennifer DeVince said. "Although sometimes he lets kids egg him on to make some noise when we're driving on the street."
Gary DeVince and his brothers Nick and Dean bought the Mustang from its original owner for $500 in 1972, and drove it throughout their high school years. He got possession of it after he came home from a stint in the U.S. Coast Guard, and began restoring it in the 1990s, doing most of the work himself.
"I've had a lot of fun with this car over the years," he said. "From when we were kids cruising on E Street to now. It's always been a San Bernardino car."
The original Route 66 Rendezvous has always been a San Bernardino event, despite many obstacles and some changes to the venue. Founded in 1990 by the San Bernardino Convention & Visitors Bureau and now rechristened and run by the San Bernardino Area Chamber of Commerce, the Rendezvous boasts a 25-year history of celebrating the internal combustion engine.
Open to car models from 1900 to 1974, it draws classics, muscle cars, hot rods and trucks. Once a four-day, three-night extravaganza that covered 35 blocks, the Rendezvous has scaled down in recent years, and even moved out of downtown to San Manuel Stadium.
"It's good to have it back downtown," Gary DeVince said.
Leo Rivas of Colton, like the DeVinces a member of the E Street Cruizers car club, said the Route 66 Rendezvous inspired him to start restoring cars, including the candy-apple red 1948 Chevrolet pickup he was showing off Saturday.
"It's a lot of work," he said. "But I'm living the dream."
Contact the writer: Laurie.editor@gmail.com
